qas.question: What is another term for a completed play?
How many plays can the offence run without gaining ten yards?
How many downs does a team get after they've gained ten on their first down?
What does a team do when they have not advance the ball enough to score or likely gain a new set of downs?
What is a forfeit play called?

plausible_answers.text: advance the ball at least ten yards towards the opponents' goal line within three downs

qas.question: What must the offence do within 10 yards or forfeit the ball?

plausible_answers.text: in an attempt to advance the ball and gain a cumulative 10 yards

qas.question: What can a team use its 10 yards to gain?
How many field goals does a team get after they've gained ten on their first down?
What does a team do in their position on the field when they haven't advanced the ball enough to score?

context: Each play constitutes <b4_0>a <a0_0>down<b4_0/><a0_0/>. The offence must <b5_0>advance the ball at least ten yards towards the opponents' goal line within <a1_0><b7_0>three<b7_0/><a1_0/> downs<b5_0/> or forfeit the ball to their opponents. Once ten yards have been gained the offence gains a new set of three downs (rather than the four downs given in American football). Downs do not accumulate. If the offensive team completes 10 yards on their first play, they lose the other two downs and are granted another set of <a2_0>three<a2_0/>. If a team fails to gain ten yards in two downs they usually <a3_0><b8_0>punt<a3_0/> the ball<b8_0/> on third down or try to kick a field goal (see below), depending on their position on the field. The team may, however use its third down <b6_0>in an attempt to advance the ball and gain a cumulative 10 yards<b6_0/>.
